head.supplied: Australian Fungi ¶ M C Cooke ¶ ¶ April 4/1885 ¶ My dear Baron ¶ ¶ I have received 2 or 3 letters from you to which I have not replied ¶ (I) Because postage is so heavy until your Government will ad...

div.p: RB MSS M86B, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;

div.p:
The list is one of a number sent by Cooke that are now in the library of the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne. Australian Fungi
Unless otherwise noted, each name in the list has a ✓ to its left. Note that these fungi had not necessarily been sent to Cooke by M. Some bear numbers, but there is no key to them provided.

cell.p:
Clavaria botrytes
C. botrytis? FNI gives Persoon as the author, not Fries. Fr

Boletus (subtomentosus Fr ?)
FNI gives Linnaeus as the author, not Fries. There is no ✓ against this name.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

cell.p:
Ag.
Agaricus. (Crepidotus) pactolus Cke
Non-standard abbreviation for Cooke; M listed '[Agaricus] pactolus, Cooke (Crepidotus)' in B85.10.04 without description, and no formal publication has been found (FNI and Index fungorum, accessed 4 April 2021).

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;

cell.p:
Moona N E
Probably 'Moona Plains' a grazing property near Walcha, New Englnd (NSW), from where Alexander Crawford sent specimens to M; see, for example, A. Crawford to M, 1884 (in this edition as 84-00-00f).

cell.style: padding-left: 0.075in; padding-right: 0.075in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

Poronia punctata Fr (sub Ascobolus ([cr]awfordi)
No name similar to Ascobolus crawfordi has been found (FNI and Index fungorum, accessed 4 April 2021).

Namoi River, NSW.

cell.p:
Luttit Bay (Beal)
Now Lorne, Vic; probably Amy Beal, who is known to have collected algae for M there (see J. Agardh to M, 30 April 1885).

cell.p:
Polyporus sanguineus Fr
Compare with the earlier entry for this species, where the author is given as 'B'; FNI gives Meyer as the author of this combination, not Fries. There is no ✓ against this name.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

div.p: The remaining text is at the bottom of the second page of the sheet. My dear Baron

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

div.p:
I have received 2 or 3 letters from you to which I have not replied
Letters not found. (I) Because postage is so heavy until your Government will adopt Postal Cards (2) Because I had but little to say.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt;

div.p:
As far as I can I will save you specimens of Australian Fungi, but hitherto duplicates were handed over to Kew. I have already a number laid aside for you. My "Illustrations" occupy an immense time as I do not employ an artist at all but draw all myself and color the patterns.
Cooke (1881-91). This with the revision of all
Pyrenomycetes
Cooke published his 'Synopsis Pyrenomycetum' across several issues of Grevillea, commencing with Cooke (1884) and concluding with Cooke (1891). The articles were reprinted in Cooke (1886-91). and a proposed Monograph of
Polyporus
The proposed monograph was not published but Cooke issued in seven parts his 'preliminary lists, imperfect though they may be, in order to indicate the arrangement we have decided to adopt' (Cooke (1885), p. 80), with the last issued as Cooke (1886-7), pp. 50-60. are about sufficient work for 2 or 3 men. Excuse this short note — as you want the above list.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
